pages.text: The following options are available to route mechanical power from $(bold)A/$ to $(bold)B/$:$(br)$(li)Shafts$(li)Cogwheels$(li)Large Cogwheels$(li)Gearboxes$(li)Encased Chain Drives$(li)Mechanical Belts$(p)Each one has its particular use case, so you'll benefit

greatly from understanding them all, and keeping them in mind when you wish to connect your machines together.$(p)Again, this is a perfect place to use the $(bold)ponder/$ feature from Create:$(br)When you hold $(bold)[$(k:key.forward)]/$ while your mouse is over most items from Create, it opens an interface that shows you the uses of that item $(italic)interactively/$.$(p)Try it out on the items in the following pages!
Pretty $(italic)straight/$-forward:$(br)This most basic element simply moves power in a straight line.
Small $(item)cogwheels/$ connect to their neighbors, rotating the other direction as a result.

The $(item)large cogwheel/$ will connect to other large cogwheels to rotate 90Â°, as well as to smaller $(item)cogwheels/$ diagonally on the same plane, which changes the $(l:basics/04_controlling_speed)gear ratio/$.This latter mechanic will be very important very soon.
If you need something more compact than $(item)large cogwheels/$, you can use $(item)gearboxes/$, which come as a horizontal and vertical variant.$(p)Opposite sides will rotate opposite directions.

When you need neighboring shafts rotating the $(italic)same/$ direction (unlike $(item)cogwheels/$), $(item)encased chain drives/$ shine.$(p)Neighboring, connected drives turn the same direction, and can even be rotated.
The only downside: You need$(br)to first $(l:renewables/05_metals)get some iron/$.

$(item)Belts/$ have a similar use-case to $(item)encased chain drives/$, able to bridge larger distances and go diagonally up and down.$(p)However, $(item)belts/$ require power depending on their speed, unlike the previous options.
They also $(thing)move items/$ but that's less relevant in this chapter.
